Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SaTC: Collaborative: Addressing Social Media-Related Cybersecurity and Privacy Risks with Experiential Learning Interventions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this work is to create and evaluate experiential learning interventions to address privacy and cybersecurity risks at scale, particularly around populations with special privacy and security needs. These experiential learning interventions will provide both instructional content and customizable, realistic simulations of various social media environments in which to practice it; an initial platform for developing these interventions, along with a small set of pilot interventions aimed at general middle school audiences, have already been developed as part of the Social Media TestDrive initiative. Building on those resources, the first main aim of the project is to identify youth subgroups for whom the pilot interventions are less effective, then develop versions of those interventions targeted to the unique needs and characteristics of those subgroups. This will be done by integrating methods from inclusive privacy research and contextual inquiry, both of which aim to develop deep understanding of subgroups in a larger population. The second main aim is to explore the potential for experiential learning-based interventions across the lifespan, through doing formative work with older adults to identify their particular privacy needs and concerns and developing an intervention suited to those needs. The third main aim is to enhance the platform’s content creation and data collection capabilities, in order to make it more widely available for social media simulation-based interventions. Together, these activities expand the quality, scope, and impact of research around simulation-based educational interventions for privacy and security.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work under this award advanced experiential learning interventions to address social-media-related cybersecurity and privacy risks for different populations. Towards this end, we explored the development of novel tools to contextualize and customize experiential learning through AI chatbot-based applications and evaluated how active engagement in different phases of experiential learning predicted social media literacy knowledge across diverse youth groups. In addition to demonstrating the robustness of the experiential learning interventions to address privacy and cybersecurity risks at scale, our effort produced a new Youth Social Media Literacy measurement scale to assess youth's social media knowledge through an objective knowledge test. By focusing on digital risks and harms, we advanced our understanding of the complex digital-safety landscape of attackers, threats, and harms. We also identified protective practices employed by youth and adults to prevent and mitigate digital risks, as well as critical barriers to their implementation. Furthermore, our research contributed to understanding the empowerment aspect of digital literacy by developing a Critical Social Media Literacy framework grounded in users' goals, contextual use, inquiry, reflection, and action. By extending our work from youth to adults, we contributed to understanding digital parenting divides and how parental efforts to mitigate digital risks and enhance youth's digital well-being reflect their available resources, digital skills, and online safety attitudes. The findings around digital parenting divides further underscore the importance of tailored interventions to address cybersecurity and digital literacy gaps, especially those geared to vulnerable populations' unique needs and characteristics. Finally, we employed our existing online delivery mechanisms through the Social Media TestDrive program used by over 800,000 learners to date and our partnerships with various media literacy organizations to disseminate cybersafety and privacy resources and raise awareness of digital risks and well-being. 


Last Modified: 06/01/2023
Modified by: Natalya N Bazarova

By focusing on digital risks and harms, we advanced our understanding of the complex digital-safety landscape of attackers, threats, and harms. Furthermore, our research contributed to understanding the empowerment aspect of digital literacy by developing a Critical Social Media Literacy framework grounded in users' goals, contextual use, inquiry, reflection, and action.
